div.sent: Everyday a lot of changes are taking place in the world.
The water of the rivers and canals change to vapour due to the heat of the sun.
The vapour condenses to clouds and then we have rains from the clouds.
There are high and low tides in rivers.
Nights follow days.
Seeds germinate into plants, leaves grow out of the plants, flowers bloom, trees give fruits, they are ripen.
Finally, we get seeds from fruits.
Cooking is done in the kitchen.
Curds, ghee, butter, cheese, etc are made of milk.
Sweets are made of milk.
Puffed rice, flattened rice and cakes are made of rice.
Oil, coal and gas burn.
Many such changes are taking place around us every day.
If you observe carefully, you will see that all these changes are of the same kind.
In one type of change the main constituent of a matter does not change.
On the other hand, the main substance changes into completely different substance in the case of some other changes.
Thus we see that there are two types of changes such as physical changes and chemical changes.
The major cause of a chemical change is chemical reaction.
In this chapter we shall discuss the chemical changes and chemical reactions.
Let us discuss first what a chemical reaction is.
The process through which one or more substances change to one or more new substances of completely different properties is called a chemical reaction.
Similarly, let us consider the case of sodium and chlorine.
Chemical Reaction and Chemical Equation 29.
At normal temperatures, sodium is a soft and white metal.
It consists of sodium atoms.
On the other hand, chlorine is a greenish yellow poisonous gas having a bad smell.
It is a diatomic gas.
This is a chemical reaction.
In the above example, sodium and chlorine are the reactants and sodium chloride is the product.
During any chemical reaction atoms are rearranged.
The reactants sodium and chlorine lose their individual properties to form sodium chloride through chemical reaction.
This is our edible salt.
During a chemical reaction a new substance is formed through the re-arrangement of atoms and molecules.
For this reason, the original reactants cannot be easily obtained from the new substance formed through the chemical reaction.
A question may come to your mind, Why does chemical reaction take place?
Can any substance react with another one?
There must be strong attractions between the reactants for a chemical reaction to occur.
This attraction among the reactants is called chemical affinity.
In addition to this, suitable conditions such as temperature, pressure, electricity, etc. are to required to start a chemical reaction.
These conditions may not be applicable to all reactions but specific conditions are applicable to run specific reactions.
A chemical reaction does not take place without the specific conditions needed for that particular reaction.
For example, if you put both hydrogen and oxygen together in a flask for many years, water will not be produced.
But if electricity is passed through the mixture of hydrogen and oxygen, water will form immediately.
When solid ice is heated, it changes to water, and when water is boiled, it changes to steam.
Again, when steam is cooled slowly, it becomes liquid and then ice.
Water, ice and steam are three different forms of the same substance .
The molecules of ice, water and steam have the same composition.
These are physical changes when an electric current is passed through the acidified water.
Water is decomposed into hydrogen and oxygen.
Water does not remain water.
Hydrogen and oxygen do not produce water at normal conditions.
This will bring about a change in the composition of molecules totally.
Therefore, chemical changes change the specific properties of matters by bringing about a change in the composition of their molecules.
New molecules are formed as a result of a chemical change.
Chemical changes occur due to chemical reactions.
There are various factors, such as heat, pressure, electric current, atmosphere, presence of acid, light etc.
They play important roles in chemical reactions.
Physical change Chemical change Chemical changes.
Physical change is temporary.
There is no change in mass of the substance due to physical change.
Thermal change may or may not occurs.
Chemical changes are those changes which alter the specific properties of the matter by bringing about a change in the composition of its molecules.
Completely new molecules are formed as a result of chemical changes.
Chemical change is permanent.
Always a new substance or substances are produced.
Thermal exchange must always occur during chemical change.
Numerous chemical reactions are occurring around us naturally as well as artificially.
It is quite difficult to explain chemical reactions with our ordinary vocabulary.
Symbols and formulas are used to remember the names of elements or compounds easily.
The chemical reactions are adequately with the chemical equations.
Chemical reactions are written in two parts.
One part contains the reactants and in the other part the products or the newly formed substances.
Reactants represent the prior state of the reaction and products the resultant state of the chemical reaction.
In any chemical reaction, atoms cannot be created or destroyed; but they are re-arranged only.
The total number of atoms present in the reactants before the reaction always equals the total number of atoms of the product after the reaction.
So the reactants and their product have the same number of atoms.
A chemical equation is a shortened expression of a chemical reaction.
It uses some symbols, formulas and some mathematical signs to denote the reactants and the products.
It also denotes the equality between the reactant and their products.
If the reactants or products are more than one, a plus (+) sign is put between the formula and the symbols.
If the number of molecule is more than one then the number is used before the formula.
An arrow sign (?) is used to indicate that the reaction moves towards the products from the reactants.
Instead of an arrow sign, an equals sign (=) may also be used.
However, the equation has to be balanced on both sides.
So, to make balance the symbol or formula must be multiplied by the required number.
Hydrogen reacts with oxygen to produce water.
The number of H and O-atoms before the reaction and their numbers after the reaction should be same.
But in reaction 2 & 3 only two elements combine to form a compound.
So, they are called synthesis reactions.
All synthesis reactions are addition reactions, but all addition reactions are not synthesis reactions.
The reaction in which a compound is split up into two or more molecules of different substance is called decomposition.
It is the opposite reaction of addition reaction.
But when a compound is decomposed into two or more elements the reaction is called analysis reaction.
The three reactions shown above are the examples of decomposition reaction.
But in reactions 2 and 3 one compound is decomposed into elements, these two are called analysis reactions.
All analysis reactions include decomposition reactions, but all decomposition reactions do not include analysis reactions.
The reaction in which one element displaces or substitutes another element in a compound is called a substitution reaction.
In this reaction zinc displaces copper from copper sulphate solution to form metallic copper.
When two compounds react and form two new compounds through an exchange of atoms or radicals, it is called a double decomposition reaction.
In these examples, Ag exchanges its position with sodium and nitrate exchange position with chlorine.
The reaction in which acids and bases react with one another to form water and salt is called a neutralization reaction.
When a substance is burnt in presence of oxygen or air to produce a different compound, the process is called combustion.

Suppose the valency of A is x and that of B is y.
Then the molecular formula of AB will be AyBx.

In this case the formula of element and radical is written side by side.
If the valencies are multiplied by any whole number, then the valencies are exchanged after a division by the whole number.
